title: Data Normalization and Transformation
text: Full Documentation & Tutorials: https://gonrui.github.io/prepkit/ â€œZ-Score fails, use M-Score.â€ prepkit comprehensive R package designed prepkitocessing longitudinal behavioral data, specific focus gerontology, digital health, sensor analytics. flagship feature M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization), novel algorithm designed detect anomalies data characterized â€œhabitual plateausâ€ (e.g., daily step counts, heart rate), traditional methods like Z-Score Min-Max scaling often fail due skewed distributions high-frequency routine noise.

title: Data Normalization and Transformation
text: prepkit rigorously tested Linux, macOS, Windows, compatibility verified R 4.5 (development version). can install stable version GitHub:

what: ğŸ“Š Quick Start: The Power of M-Score
title: Data Normalization and Transformation
text: Real-world sensor data often contains routine plateaus (e.g., older adult consistently walking 3000 steps) sensor noise (floating-point jitter). M-Score handles elegantly:
code: library(prepkit)  # 1. Simulate Sensor Data # - Routine: ~3000 steps (with sensor jitter like 3000.1, 2999.9) # - Anomaly: 200 steps (Fall/Frailty) # - Anomaly: 6000 steps (Hyperactivity) steps <- c(3000.1, 3000.2, 2999.8, 200.0, 3000.0, 6000.0)  # 2. Apply M-Score (with precision protection) # The 'digits' parameter rounds values internally to identify the semantic mode, # while preserving the precision of the anomalies. m_scores <- norm_mode_range(steps, digits = 0)  # 3. View Results print(data.frame(Raw = steps, M_Score = m_scores))

title: Data Normalization and Transformation
text: M-Score transforms data based Mode Interval (routine plateau). Unlike Z-Score penalizes stability (low variance), M-Score treats frequent range â€œSafe Zoneâ€ (Score = 0). transformation function M(x)M(x) defined : M(x)={âˆ’kLâˆ’xkLâˆ’kminif x<kL(Left Tail / Frailty)0if kLâ‰¤xâ‰¤kR(Routine Plateau)xâˆ’kRkmaxâˆ’kRif x>kR(Right Tail / Hyper) M(x) = \begin{cases}    -\frac{k_L - x}{k_L - k_{min}} & \text{} x < k_L \quad (\text{Left Tail / Frailty}) \\    0 & \text{} k_L \le x \le k_R \quad (\text{Routine Plateau}) \\    \frac{x - k_R}{k_{max} - k_R} & \text{} x > k_R \quad (\text{Right Tail / Hyper}) \end{cases} Validated via symbolic computation (Wolfram Mathematica) strict monotonicity.

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
text: Normalizes numeric vector moving decimal point values attribute . number decimal points moved depends maximum absolute value .

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
text: x numeric vector. na.rm Logical. NA values ignored determining scaling factor? Default TRUE.

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
text: numeric vector values typically range (-1, 1).

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
text: Formula: \(x' = \frac{x}{10^j}\) \(j\) smallest integer \(\max(|x'|) < 1\).

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
text: Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data mining: concepts techniques (3rd ed.). Morgan Kaufmann.

title: Decimal Scaling Normalization â€” norm_decimal
code: # Max value is 980, so j=3 (divides by 1000) -> 0.98 norm_decimal(c(10, 500, 980)) #> [1] 0.01 0.50 0.98  # Works with negative numbers norm_decimal(c(-50, 50, 200)) #> [1] -0.05  0.05  0.20

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
text: Scales vector Euclidean norm (L2 norm) 1. technique often used text mining high-dimensional clustering, related spatial sign prepkitocessing robust statistics.

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
text: x numeric vector. na.rm Logical. Remove NAs norm calculation? Default TRUE.

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
text: numeric vector L2 norm 1.

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
text: Formula: \(x' = \frac{x}{\sqrt{\sum x^2}}\)

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
text: Serneels, S., De Nages, E., & Van Espen, P. J. (2006). Spatial sign prepkitocessing: simple way impart moderate robustness multivariate estimators. Journal Chemical Information Modeling, 46(3), 1402-1409. doi:10.1021/ci050498u Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data mining: concepts techniques (3rd ed.). Morgan Kaufmann.

title: L2 Normalization (Unit Vector) â€” norm_l2
code: # Convert a vector to unit length x <- c(3, 4) norm_l2(x) # Returns c(0.6, 0.8) #> [1] 0.6 0.8

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
text: Scales numeric vector centering around mean scaling range. resulting vector mean 0 values typically within [-1, 1].

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
text: x numeric vector. na.rm Logical. NA values removed calculation? Default TRUE.

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
text: numeric vector.   range 0 (values identical), returns centered vector (zeros).

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
text: Formula: \(x' = \frac{x - \text{mean}(x)}{\max(x) - \min(x)}\)

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
text: Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data mining: concepts techniques (3rd ed.). Morgan Kaufmann.

title: Mean Normalization â€” norm_mean
code: # Result ranges from approx -0.5 to 0.5, mean is 0 norm_mean(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)) #> [1] -0.50 -0.25  0.00  0.25  0.50  # Handles negative values norm_mean(c(-10, 0, 10)) #> [1] -0.5  0.0  0.5

title: Min-Max Normalization â€” norm_minmax
text: Scales numeric vector specific range, typically [0, 1]. method sensitive outliers.

title: Min-Max Normalization â€” norm_minmax
text: x numeric vector. min_val minimum value target range. Default 0. max_val maximum value target range. Default 1. na.rm Logical. NA values removed min/max calculation? Default TRUE.

title: Min-Max Normalization â€” norm_minmax
text: numeric vector scaled range [min_val, max_val].

title: Min-Max Normalization â€” norm_minmax
text: Formula: \(x' = \frac{x - \min(x)}{\max(x) - \min(x)} \times (\text{max\_val} - \text{min\_val}) + \text{min\_val}\)

title: Min-Max Normalization â€” norm_minmax
text: Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data mining: concepts techniques (3rd ed.). Morgan Kaufmann.

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
text: Unlike Z-Score Min-Max, M-Score algorithm identifies "Mode Range" (frequent value range) maps 0. effectively suppresses noise daily routine (e.g., stable step counts) amplifies anomalies (e.g., frailty sudden activity). maps: Mode Range: \([k_L, k_R] \0\) (Baseline/Routine) Left Tail: \([min, k_L) \[-1, 0)\) (Decline/Frailty) Right Tail: \((k_R, max] \(0, 1]\) (Surge/Hyperactivity)

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
text: x numeric vector. tau numeric value (0 1). threshold ratio defining mode plateau. Bins freq >= tau * max_freq considered part routine. Default 0.8. digits Integer NULL. NULL, values rounded many decimal places solely identifying mode. makes algorithm robust sensor noise (e.g., 1.0001 vs 1.0002). Default 0 (rounds integer), ideal step counts heart rates. Set NULL disable rounding.

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
text: numeric vector range [-1, 1].

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
text: robust normalization method designed longitudinal behavioral data "routine plateau". Also known Mode-Range Normalization (MRN).

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
text: Gong, R. (2026). M-Score: Robust Normalization Method Detecting Anomalies Longitudinal Behavioral Data. arXiv prepkitint. (Submitted)

title: M-Score (Mode-Range Normalization) â€” norm_mode_range
code: # Scenario 1: Integer data (Standard) steps <- c(3000, 3000, 200, 5000) norm_mode_range(steps) #> [1]  0  0 -1  1  # Scenario 2: Noisy Sensor Data (Floating point) # Without 'digits', these would be seen as different values. # With digits=1, they are grouped into the same mode. sensor_data <- c(9.81, 9.82, 9.80, 2.5, 15.0) norm_mode_range(sensor_data, digits = 1) #> [1]  0  0  0 -1  1

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
text: Standardizes numeric vector using robust statistics: median median absolute deviation (MAD). method less sensitive outliers compared Z-score standardization.

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
text: x numeric vector. na.rm Logical. NA values removed? Default TRUE. constant scale factor MAD calculation. Default 1.4826, ensures consistency standard deviation normal distributions.

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
text: numeric vector.   MAD 0 (e.g., 50   returns centered vector (x - median) issues warning.

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
text: Formula: \(x' = \frac{x - \text{median}(x)}{\text{mad}(x)}\)

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
text: Huber, P. J. (1981). Robust Statistics. Wiley. ISBN: 978-0-471-41805-4. Hampel, F. R. (1974). influence curve role robust estimation. Journal American Statistical Association, 69(346), 383-393.

title: Robust Standardization (Median-MAD) â€” norm_robust
code: # Data with an outlier x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 100)  # Z-score is heavily affected by the outlier norm_zscore(x) #> [1] -0.4814564 -0.4585299 -0.4356034 -0.4126769  1.7882666  # Robust scaler handles it better norm_robust(x) #> [1] -1.3489815 -0.6744908  0.0000000  0.6744908 65.4256037

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
text: Standardizes numeric vector centering mean 0 scaling standard deviation 1.

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
text: x numeric vector. na.rm Logical. NA values removed mean/sd calculation? Default TRUE.

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
text: numeric vector.   input vector zero variance (values identical),   function returns centered vector (zeros) issues warning.

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
text: Formula: \(z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\)

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
text: Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data mining: concepts techniques (3rd ed.). Morgan Kaufmann.

title: Z-Score Standardization â€” norm_zscore
code: # Standard usage norm_zscore(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)) #> [1] -1.2649111 -0.6324555  0.0000000  0.6324555  1.2649111  # Edge case: Zero variance norm_zscore(c(5, 5, 5)) #> Warning: Standard deviation is zero. Returning centered vector (zeros). #> [1] 0 0 0
